div1.p: [Carter] starts a letter to Mary Clayborne Carter about Gorgas, Finlay, and patients with yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter fragment from [Henry Rose Carter] to Mary Clayborne Carter, [19--]
div1.p:
It is Easter Sunday; On Easter 1920--I was able to tell
the wife of Dr. Quiroz that, barring accidents he was out of danger--he
having entered his 6th day of his fever. I had just come from seeing a
child of the Alcalde Francesca Reygada, whom I saw at 2 A.M. & for
to whom I staff c whom I stopped 3 kind of medicine & removed
4 mustard plasters. I think Of course little children generally
recover from Y.F. & Francesca was 7.--but I think she would have
died--but for stopping her treatment. I fed her ice in small pieces until she
went to sleep at 7 AM.

The Bryans--Mrs Braxton & the 2 unmarried girls YFinlay
and we were glad to see [unclear]. The youngest son--Braxton is in Balt.
on the Evening Sun.

Mrs Gorgas returned from Habvana Friday & I am exceedingly
glad that Hendrix accepted some of my suggested chan-
ges in the MS of “Gorgas in Havana”. He has spoken very
slightingly about Carlos Finlay & from ignorance, un-
justly so. The paper comes out with a small compliment
instead. Indeed he, Hendrix, expressed all of the real-
ly objectionable matter of which there was considerable but
he has three fundamental errors, which except from
the historical standpoint do no harm, about which he
knew better.
